results.title: Angkor, the lost city
results.brief_description: Angkor - a whole metropolis of palaces and temples recovered from the jungle which hid them for centuries until discovered in 1860 by a French naturalist. Monuments, picture tapestries in stone and Angkor Vat, a mile square temple of grey sandstone which no other church has rivalled in size, reveal the glories of the past empire of the Khmers, ancestors of the Cambodians.

results.title: Don't Think I Don't Think
results.brief_description: Documents an important conference on rights for the disabled held at Melbourne University in 1981. The disabled groups present drew up a charter of rights- rights to work, to live in their own houses etc. free of the constraints that paternalistic institutions impose

results.title: Wildness
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Big and Little Films, Michael McMahon and Scott Millwood
results.brief_description: Tasmanian landscape photographers Olegas Truchanas and Peter Dombrovskis had much in common. Born 22 years apart both came from Baltic Europe and migrated to Tasmania, where they developed a passion for visiting and photographing the island’s remote, wild places. Both men died before their time in the wilderness doing what they loved, and left a legacy of stunning landscape and nature photography which became synonymous with campaigns to protect Tasmania’s natural heritage. They believed that if people could see the beauty of Australia’s wild places then they might be moved to save them. Through the sixties and seventies Truchanas raised public awareness about the beauty and uniqueness of the Tasmanian wilderness, and the threat to it posed by the Tasmanian government’s massive hydro-electric schemes, through his now legendary slide presentations. After his death his work was carried on by Dombrovskis who published his images in calendars and allowed them to be used freely in the successful campaign to save the Franklin River from hydro-electric development. Combining interviews and archival footage with over 300 photographs by Truchanas and Dombrowskis, ‘Wildness’ is an accomplished tribute to the two men’s invaluable contribution to both visual culture and environmental awareness in Australia. Narrated by Nina Landis. Teachers notes are available from the Film Australia website. [www.filmaust.com.au]

results.title: Half a Chance
results.creator_credit: Seven Dimensions, Film Victoria, Eve Ash and Ted Robinson
results.brief_description: A collection of dramatised case studies of young offenders on probation. Both the probationer and the probation officer talk about the problems and advantages of this type of supervision.

results.title: Gordon splits
results.creator_credit: Sydney Filmmakers Co-operative, Wilderness Society (Australia) and Michael Cordell
results.brief_description: Peter Dombrovskis, Australia’s foremost Wilderness photographer, photographs two spectacular gorges in South West Tasmania. He talks about his own experience of wilderness and the threat of flooding.

results.title: Vasili's garden
results.brief_description: Welcome to Vasili’s Garden, a fun and very organic gardening show with lots of entertainment. Vasili enters people’s lives via the garden gate and together with the garden’s creator he delves into the private world beyond the backyard fence exploring their gardening obsessions and fantasies, sharing their tips and common sense. A tour around everyday gardens presented in both Greek and English with helpful tips and advice.

results.title: RAW. Episode 3
results.creator_credit: Big Dog Productions, Nick McInerney, Josh Lefers, Stephen Wools and C31 Melbourne
results.brief_description: AIRED 19 April 2006. RAW is fast becoming a cult classic. The show follows Josh and Steve on urban adventures and into social experiments: from racing trams and street sweepers, to stealing bibles and creating a revolutionary system of economy with their epic Freeshit ManTM. These boys will do anything as long as it is ridiculous.

results.title: Ticket, passport and tarot cards. Episode 18. The Star
results.brief_description: AIRED 29 December 2005 Based on a popular book from Tarot expert Linda Marson, this series is a a unique combination of personal diary, travel journal and Tarot imagery. Screened as a weekly show on Channel 31 in Melbourne, T, P and TC was a five minute filler program that screened from 1 September 2005 - 26 January 2006.
